idmodelr
  • Reference

A Function to Generate Parameter Permutations

A function to generate paramter permutations from a generic sampling function (or if not given from the inputed parameters). This function can be used to rapidly generate new parameter combinations given parameters to be varied, and scenarios to be investigated.

generate_parameter_permutations(variable_params = NULL, fixed_params = NULL,
  sample_params = NULL, excluded_params = NULL, scenarios = NULL,
  sampling_function = NULL, parameter_samples = 1, repeat_sample = TRUE,
  save = TRUE, save_name = "parameter_permutations", save_path = NULL,
  save_format = NULL, rerun = FALSE, verbose = FALSE, ...)

Arguments

variable_params

A dataframe containing any parameter variations to be investigated. If these paramters would normalling be sampled then they should be added to the excluded_params arguement.
fixed_params

A named vector of parameters that are not sampled by the sampling function. If these paramters would usually be sampled then they should be added to the excluded_params arguement.
sample_params

A named vector of paramters to be sampled. If a sampling function is not supplied these parameters will be used in the final permutation dataframe.
excluded_params

A character vector indicating which parameters should have there sampled values kept.
scenarios

A dataframe of possible scenarios to investigate. It must contain a scenario variable to identify each seperate scenarios. If parameters are included here that would normally be sampled then they should be added to the excluded_params arguement
sampling_function

A sampling function, this should be designed such that it's input is a matrix with each paramter having a named row. It should return it's output in the same format. This has been tested with the rprior function from the pomp. If not supplied defaults to passing through parameters, this may not be the required behaviour.
parameter_samples

The number of parameter samples to take, defaults to one.
repeat_sample

A logical (defaults to TRUE) which indicates if each scenario should independantly sample from the sampling function. If set to FALSE then each scenario will share the same sampled parameter set.
save

Logical specifying if the results should be saved. Defaults to TRUE.
save_name

A character string of the name the results should be saved under.
save_path

A character string indicating the saving location for the results. If not specified defaults to saving in the working directory.
save_format

If additional file formats are required, see save_data.
rerun

A logical indicating if the function should be rerun or saved results should be loaded. Defaults to FALSE.
verbose

A logical, indicating if progress messages should be printed, defaults to FALSE.
...

Additional arguements to be passed to the sampling_function.

Value

A dataframe containing sampled parameter permutations

Examples


scenarios <- tibble::data_frame(scenario = c("test_1", "test_2"), scenario_param = c(0, 1))
variable_params <-  tibble::data_frame(variable = c(0, 0.5, 1))
fixed_params <- c(fixed_1 = 2, fixed_2 = c(1, 3, 4))
sample_params <- c(sample_1 = 2, sample_2 = c(2, 1))

generate_parameter_permutations(variable_params, fixed_params, sample_params,
                                excluded_params = c("variable"), scenarios,
                                parameter_samples = 1, save = FALSE)
#> # A tibble: 6 x 11
#>   scenario variable sample scenario_param fixed_1 fixed_21 fixed_22 fixed_23
#>      <chr>    <dbl>  <int>          <dbl>   <dbl>    <dbl>    <dbl>    <dbl>
#> 1   test_1      0.0      1              0       2        1        3        4
#> 2   test_2      0.0      1              1       2        1        3        4
#> 3   test_1      0.5      1              0       2        1        3        4
#> 4   test_2      0.5      1              1       2        1        3        4
#> 5   test_1      1.0      1              0       2        1        3        4
#> 6   test_2      1.0      1              1       2        1        3        4
#> # ... with 3 more variables: sample_1 <dbl>, sample_21 <dbl>, sample_22 <dbl>
